author: Edgardo Prat
title: MamÃ¡ llora al plancharle la ropa a su hija universitaria por recordar cuando la llevaba al kinder | VIRAL | Noticias de MÃ©xico | El Imparcial
text: MamÃ¡ llora al plancharle la ropa a su hija universitaria por recordar cuando la llevaba al kinder | VIRAL Esta mujer no pudo evitar romper en llanto al planchar la falda de su hija, quien estaba a punto de graduarse de la universidad. El acto de planchar le trajo a la mente los recuerdos de cuando le preparaba el uniforme del kÃ­nder para su pequeÃ±a. MÃ‰RIDA, YucatÃ¡n.- En ocasiones, nuestras madres tienen momentos llenos de nostalgia al recordar los dÃ­as en que nos acompaÃ±aban a la escuela. Esos momentos especiales les permitÃ­an estar cerca de nosotros y cuidarnos mientras crecÃ­amos llenos de energÃ­a y curiosidad por aprender. Recientemente, Velia LÃ³pez, una usuaria de [TikTok](https://www.elimparcial.com/locurioso/2024/07/09/viral-padre-e-hijo-conquistan-tiktok-al-ponerse-a-bailar-de-manera-graciosa-en-su-casa/) originaria de MÃ©rida, YucatÃ¡n, compartiÃ³ un video conmovedor que capturÃ³ uno de esos momentos emotivos entre ella y su madre. TambiÃ©n te puede interesar: [Â¿Los recuerdas? AsÃ­ se veÃ­an Los Telechobis, la versiÃ³n mexicana de Los Teletubbies](https://www.elimparcial.com/locurioso/2024/07/08/los-recuerdas-asi-se-veian-los-telechobis-la-version-mexicana-de-los-teletubbies/) Esta conmovedora escena se ha ganado el corazÃ³n de los usuarios de redes. El video muestra cÃ³mo su madre no pudo contener las lÃ¡grimas mientras planchaba una de las faldas de Velia, quien se preparaba para presentar su examen final en la universidad. Velia habÃ­a pedido a su madre que le ayudara con la plancha, desencadenando una oleada de nostalgia en su madre al recordar los dÃ­as en que planchaba el uniforme de su hija para el kÃ­nder. â€œHago esto asÃ­ y luego recuerdo cuando la llevaba al kÃ­nder, y estoy planchando su ropitaâ€, dijo la seÃ±ora. [@velialopez11] Le pedi a mi mami que me planchara mi uniforme de la Uni y mi hermanita la grabÃ³ en modo nostalgicaðŸ¥ºte amo mamiâ¤ï¸ [#mamÃ¡] [#universidad] [#nostalgia] [#recuerdos] [#fyp] [â™¬ remember you - Dominurmom] El video, que se publicÃ³ hace apenas dos dÃ­as, ya ha alcanzado 1.7 millones de reproducciones y casi 300 mil â€œme gustaâ€, resonando profundamente en el corazÃ³n de numerosos internautas. TambiÃ©n te puede interesar: [Amigos encuentran un pacto de amistad que hicieron en su infancia: Â¡hasta le pegaron cabello!](https://www.elimparcial.com/locurioso/2024/07/08/amigos-encuentran-un-pacto-de-amistad-que-hicieron-en-su-infancia-hasta-le-pegaron-cabello/) Te recomendamos [Chica sorprende a su papÃ¡ en restaurante: Â¡lleva sus propios chiles para disfrutar la comida!](/locurioso/2024/06/08/chica-sorprende-a-su-papa-en-restaurante-lleva-sus-propios-chiles-para-disfrutar-la-comida/) [VIRAL: hombre intenta ser la envidia de sus amigos con este vÃ­deo cocinando, Â¡pero termina MAL!](/locurioso/2024/06/08/viral-hombre-intenta-ser-la-envidia-de-sus-amigos-con-este-video-cocinando-pero-termina-mal/) [Influencer reta a Taquero a viajar a la India y probar la comida callejera; termina hospitalizado](/locurioso/2024/06/08/influencer-reta-a-taquero-a-viajar-a-la-india-y-probar-la-comida-callejera-termina-hospitalizado/) [JÃ³venes ingeniosos aprovechan las habilidades de sus gatos para atrapar una polilla intrusa en su hogar | VIDEO](/locurioso/2024/06/08/jovenes-ingeniosos-aprovechan-las-habilidades-de-sus-gatos-para-atrapar-una-polilla-intrusa-en-su-hogar-video/)

author: The Raymond Corporation - (GLOBE NEWSWIRE)
title: RAYMOND NAMED TO FORBESâ€™ AMERICAâ€™S BEST MIDSIZE EMPLOYERS LIST FOR 4th CONSECUTIVE YEAR
text:
GREENE, N.Y., April 18, 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- For four consecutive years, Forbes has been honoring The Raymond Corporation as one of Americaâ€™s best midsize employers. The list recognizes employers from among 500 companies, based on an independent survey and polling of an anonymous group of employees. This year, Raymond secured the No. 5 ranking in the engineering and manufacturing sector.
â€œThis tremendous honor is a testament to all our Raymond associates, who work together to deliver excellence every day,â€ said Michael Field, president and CEO, The Raymond Corporation. â€œWeâ€™re thrilled to achieve this recognition again. And through our model of continuous improvement, weâ€™re excited to keep innovating with better thinking, processes and business.â€
The annual ranking â€” conducted in partnership with market research firm Statista â€” is based on a survey of more than 170,000 U.S.-based workers at American companies. Organizations with 1,000 to 5,000 employees are deemed midsize employers, while the companies with more than 5,000 employees are considered large. Survey respondents were asked to rate their employer and if they would recommend their employer to others. New to the methodology this year is the inclusion of data from the past three years â€” with more recent data weighted more heavily â€” to better identify companies that have been rated well consistently over time.
The Raymond Corporation is hiring for manufacturing and engineering positions, as well as multiple roles in marketing, product management, finance and more. For more details about Raymondâ€™s open positions, visit
https://careers.raymondcorp.com/careers.
For more information or to locate an authorized Raymond Solutions and Support Center, visit
www.raymondcorp.com or call 800-235-7200.
About The Raymond Corporation
The Raymond Corporation, a member of the Toyota Industries family of companies, is a leading global provider of best-in-class material handling products and intelligent intralogistics solutions. Built on principles of innovation and continuous improvement for over 100 years, Raymondâ€™s integrated automation, telematics, virtual reality and advanced energy solutions provide ways to optimize operations and bring warehouse and distribution operations to a new level of performance. RaymondÂ® electric forklift trucks are engineered to achieve increased productivity and efficiency and are designed to provide ecological and economic benefits. Raymond delivers solutions to material handling and logistics markets in North America and globally. Combining operational excellence, award-winning innovation and world-class global customer support, we work together to run better, manage smarter and keep our customers always on. For more information, visit
raymondcorp.com and follow us on YouTube and

Veiga ha rimediato una lesione del tendine del plantare gracile della gamba destra nel primo tempo di PSV-Juventus
Veiga ha rimediato una lesione del tendine del plantare gracile della gamba destra e i tempi di recupero saranno valutati in funzione della sintomatologia, come comunicato con una nota dal club bianconero.
Il calciatore dunque salterÃ  sicuramente la sfida di domenica in campionato contro il Cagliari e, probabilmente, anche le successive contro l'Empoli in Coppa Italia e col Verona ancora in campionato.

author: The University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg
title: 2024-06 - Global pandemic treaty will help fight future threats - Wits University
text: Global pandemic treaty will help fight future threats - Precious Matsoso The 194 member states of the WHO are negotiating a pandemic accord, only the second health accord after the 2003 convention against tobacco. For the past two years the World Health Organizationâ€™s 194 member states have been negotiating an international accord on [pandemic prevention, preparedness and response](https://www.who.int/news-room/questions-and-answers/item/pandemic-prevention--preparedness-and-response-accord). This was driven by the need to ensure the world is better prepared for future pandemics. The outcome of the government-led negotiations was presented to the annual meeting of the World Health Assembly in May 2024 and countries required more time to develop this first-ever global pandemic accord. Negotiations have been [extended](https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-024-01658-5) until May 2025. [Precious Matsoso](https://phasa.samrc.ac.za/PreciousMalebonaMatsoso.pdf) was appointed co-chair of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Body, which was established after governments decided, in December 2021, to develop an international pandemic agreement. She has more than 25 years of executive management experience in health matters, both nationally and internationally. She tells Nadine Dreyer about the complexities of drafting the accord and why she is optimistic about getting the deal done. Why do we need a pandemic accord? During the COVID-19 pandemic, inequitable vaccine distribution protected people in the global north but left the worldâ€™s poorest at the back of the queue. Problems arose when high-income countries were accused of stockpiling pharmaceuticals for domestic use, curbing other nationsâ€™ supplies. One [analysis](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-022-02064-y) estimated that 1.3 million people died in lower-income countries because of inequitable distribution of vaccines. In the first seven months of the worldwide COVID-19 vaccination campaign, more than [80% ](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10241610/)of the doses were concentrated in [high-income](https://msf.org.uk/sites/default/files/2022-02/World%20Bank%20list%20of%20economies%202022.pdf) and [upper-middle-income countries](https://msf.org.uk/sites/default/files/2022-02/World%20Bank%20list%20of%20economies%202022.pdf). At the heart of the proposed accord is the need to ensure equity in access to the tools needed to prevent pandemics and in access to healthcare for all people. This historic treaty will be only the second such health accord after the 2003 [Framework Convention on Tobacco Control](https://fctc.who.int/who-fctc/overview), a treaty which aims to reduce smoking around the world. What successes have been achieved so far? The very first article of the accord that got the green light was one that dealt with human resources, the health workforce. Iâ€™m very pleased it at least guarantees these workers will be protected. Remember, theyâ€™re the front line. So when we have vaccines, they must be the first to get them. Weâ€™ve also added conditions like decent work, safe working conditions and so on. And then there is finance. There, negotiations are almost done. Without finance we donâ€™t have a treaty. If you go back to the COVID-19 pandemic, some of the reasons countries failed was that preparedness was grossly underfunded. But it wasnâ€™t just about financing for preparedness; some countries did not have sufficient funds to respond to COVID. There needs to be a proper finance coordinating mechanism. There has been a debate about whether to create a new funding mechanism or to reform the [Pandemic Fund](https://fiftrustee.worldbank.org/en/about/unit/dfi/fiftrustee/fund-detail/pppr). This fund, launched in 2022 by the World Bank, was the first multilateral financing mechanism dedicated to providing grants to help low- and middle-income countries become better prepared for future pandemics. Thereâ€™s one argument that instead of creating a new fund, we need to establish how to make the Pandemic Fund work most effectively and equitably, reform its governance and address criticisms that decision-making was left in the hands of a small group of predominantly wealthy nations and philanthropies. Others have argued that there is still a need for additional funding. The argument put forward is that member states canâ€™t just ask for money. They must also invest in pandemic preparedness. There must also be a systematic way of identifying gaps. There are also provisions that allow for domestic financing as countries canâ€™t just wait for handouts; itâ€™s a sign of commitment on their part. Proper assessments have to be conducted to identify gaps. But we have people and we have money, so at least you can do something towards fighting future pandemics. What are the remaining stumbling blocks? This depends on whether you see the glass half full or half empty. I see the glass as half full. My view is that some negotiators, because of their ideology, will still hold the same position even when given extensions. Ten years later they will stick to their positions. This means we needed to find another way of resolving this. We started seeing different groups being formed such as Friends of the Treaty, created to push for the pandemic treaty as at the time perceptions were that others were not serious about the accord. Others, like the Group for Equity, mainly from developing countries, argued for pathogen access and benefit-sharing on an equal footing. Friends of One Health, mostly from Europe and the UK, wanted the whole agreement to be framed by One Health, a concept which looks at the relationship between people, animals, plants and our environment. There was a call for informal meetings among member states where they could negotiate among themselves. The beauty of informal meetings and consultations was that it encouraged dialogue because I also think we were dealing with trust issues. The developed countries, including the US, with a handful of developing countries like South Africa, felt very strongly about supply chain and logistics: identifying medicines and vaccines and quantities needed, and transparency in cost, pricing and other relevant data on products, including raw materials. Two of the most difficult negotiations centre on a Pathogen Access and Benefit-Sharing System and technology transfer. - Pathogen Access and Benefit-Sharing System: disagreements centre on sharing information about pathogens that cause pandemics and a formula for global sharing of vaccines and medicine during international health emergencies. The African region and Group for Equity were adamant that without pathogen sharing there would be no pandemic treaty. They wanted access to genetic resources and pathogen samples from developing countries to be met with the shared benefits that were produced by them, such as vaccines and diagnostics. - Technical transfer: this is geographically diversified production through mechanisms such as compulsory licensing and product information, in particular for the benefit of developing countries. Developed countries have voiced support for voluntary technology transfer goals in the agreement, but they have been critical of including language that requires mandatory technology transfer. When we started the whole process, the World Health Assembly said before we wrote anything on paper we had to get input from all 194 countries. The member states had to tell us what substantive elements had to be included in the pandemic treaty, which was complex as obviously there were diverse views, different perspectives and priorities with tight deadlines. It was a highly prescriptive process with tight deadlines So throughout the process all [194 member states](https://www.who.int/countries) have stated their positions on all the articles of the treaty. Some wanted gender included in the wording of the treaty, some donâ€™t. Some want equity language, liability, and compensation provisions. Others donâ€™t. The complexity was: how do we come up with something that will be acceptable to all parties? Clearly, the Pandemic Treaty has to be balanced but not weak. If you have very weak text, that is not going to be helpful at all. Nothing will change, it will just be maintaining the status quo. So we need a bit of time to find alternative language and to find ways to convince some about outstanding issues. I am confident that we can come to an agreement and complete this treaty within the next year. [Precious Matsoso](https://theconversation.com/profiles/precious-matsoso-1541564), Academic and treaty negotiator, [University of the Witwatersrand. ](https://theconversation.com/institutions/university-of-the-witwatersrand-894)This article is republished from [The Conversation](https://theconversation.com) under a Creative Commons license. Read the [original article](https://theconversation.com/global-pandemic-treaty-will-help-fight-future-threats-top-negotiator-on-how-talks-are-going-232441).

author: Anosha Shariq
title: SonicWall VPN Flaw Exposed: Hackers Predict Session IDs
text:
San Francisco, January 10, 2025 â€“SonicWall VPNs face a new vulnerability, allowing hackers to predict session IDs and access sensitive networks. A patch is available; immediate updates are urged.
Ethical hackers from Computest Security have uncovered a critical flaw in SonicWall VPN servers, marking the second vulnerability in recent months. This flaw allows attackers to predict session IDs, enabling them to impersonate legitimate users and infiltrate sensitive corporate networks.
The vulnerability, found at the login stage, revolves around the systemâ€™s session ID mechanism. Hackers can predict these unique identifiers, designed to verify users during VPN sessions. Once exploited, the flaw lets attackers move through the network undetected, potentially accessing confidential data.
This is a wake-up call for enterprises relying on SonicWall VPNs. It highlights the urgent need to fortify peripheral security systems.
In October 2024, SonicWall VPNs were similarly targeted by ransomware campaigns. Despite recent patches, the recurrence of vulnerabilities underscores the persistent risks businesses face. Computest Security promptly reported this flaw to SonicWall, and a patch is now available.
VPNs are supposed to be the first line of defense. Flaws like this could jeopardize critical infrastructure, from small businesses to global enterprises.
As more organizations adopt remote work, business VPNs play an essential role in securing data. However, incidents like these emphasize the importance of regular updates, robust passwords, and employee cybersecurity training.
topics: Science and Technology->information technology and computer science
Economy, Business and Finance->computing and information technology

author: Caitlin Rogers
title: ABW Appliances - Shop Maryland Energy
text:
President's Day weekend is also Maryland Energy Weekend, and if you're looking to purchase or upgrade an appliance, it's the best time to buy!
While Black Friday traditionally offers sale prices, Shop Maryland Energy savings stack on top of manufacture rebates and store deals, making it the perfect time to purchase. Qualifying Energy Star Certified appliances are tax free during Maryland Energy Weekend, February 17-19.
ABW Appliances offers white glove full service from shopping through warranty. Installers are factory-certified and managed in-house, not outsourced to third-party contractors. They have a wide selection of Energy Star appliances, which help save money and the environment. Qualifying appliances available at ABW include standard size refrigerators, clothes washers, clothes dryers, and combination laundry units.
ABW also offers 3% instant cash back for customers to use towards haul away fees, special installation, delivery, and more.
Learn more here , and Shop Maryland Energy February 17-19.

author: SchoolTube Community
title: Americaâ€™s Stealthy Might: Unveiling the B-2 Spirit
text:
The B-2 Spirit: A Symbol of American Air Power
The B-2 Spirit, also known as the Stealth Bomber, is a remarkable aircraft that has captured the attention and respect of military enthusiasts and adversaries alike. Developed by the United States Air Force, the B-2 represents the pinnacle of aviation engineering and technological innovation. In this blog post, we will delve into the reasons why Americaâ€™s enemies fear this exceptional aircraft and explore its unique features that make it such a formidable force.
Unmatched Stealth Capabilities One of the most defining characteristics of the B-2 Spirit is its unparalleled stealth capabilities. The aircraft is designed using a combination of advanced materials and innovative shaping techniques, making it virtually undetectable by radar systems. This stealthiness allows the B-2 to penetrate deep into enemy territory without being detected, providing it with a significant advantage in combat situations.
The B-2â€™s stealth features include:
Low-Observable Design: The B-2â€™s unique shape and construction minimize its radar cross-section, making it difficult for enemy radar systems to detect. Radar-Absorbing Materials: The aircraft is coated with special materials that absorb radar waves, further reducing its detectability. Engine Inlet Design: The B-2â€™s engine inlets are designed to minimize the emission of infrared radiation, making it less visible to heat-seeking missiles. Impressive Range and Payload Capacity In addition to its stealth capabilities, the B-2 Spirit boasts an impressive range and payload capacity. The aircraft can fly long distances without refueling, allowing it to reach targets deep within enemy territory. It can also carry a substantial payload of conventional or nuclear weapons, making it capable of delivering devastating strikes with precision.
The B-2â€™s range and payload capabilities include:
Long Range: The B-2 has a range of approximately 6,000 miles (9,656 kilometers), enabling it to reach targets across vast distances. Heavy Payload: The aircraft can carry up to 40,000 pounds (18,144 kilograms) of weapons, including precision-guided munitions and nuclear bombs. Advanced Avionics and Sensors The B-2 Spirit is equipped with state-of-the-art avionics and sensors that provide the crew with unparalleled situational awareness and targeting capabilities. These systems allow the aircraft to navigate precisely, identify targets with accuracy, and deliver weapons with pinpoint precision.
The B-2â€™s advanced avionics and sensors include:
Integrated Flight Control System: The B-2â€™s flight control system provides precise handling and stability, even during low-altitude missions. Synthetic Aperture Radar: The aircraft is equipped with a synthetic aperture radar that produces high-resolution images of the ground, allowing the crew to identify targets with greater accuracy. Electro-Optical Targeting System: The B-2â€™s targeting system uses advanced sensors to identify and track targets, ensuring precise weapon delivery. A Force to be Reckoned With The combination of stealth, range, payload capacity, and advanced avionics makes the B-2 Spirit a formidable force in modern warfare. Its ability to penetrate enemy defenses undetected and deliver devastating strikes has earned it the respect and fear of Americaâ€™s adversaries. The B-2 Spirit stands as a testament to the United Statesâ€™ commitment to maintaining technological superiority and ensuring national security.
As the USAF plans to modernize the B-2 platform, we can expect this exceptional aircraft to continue to play a vital role in safeguarding Americaâ€™s interests and deterring potential threats for decades to come.
